awd_titl_txt: Experimental Physics Research Program at Columbia University/Nevis Laboratories
awd_abstract_narration:
The Columbia University High Energy Physics group covers activities in three major programs: the ATLAS experiment at the LHC, MicroBooNE and the Short Baseline Neutrino (SBN) program at Fermilab, and the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE) at Fermilab and South Dakota. The group also participates in the Coherent Captain Mills (CCM) experiment, has roles in DUNE construction, and a major role in the ATLAS High Luminosity upgrades. 

Particle physics addresses fundamental questions at a range from subatomic to cosmic scales. The Standard Model (SM) is believed to be only an approximate theory, and new physics beyond the SM will hold the key to making progress in understanding the underlying theory. Some of the most important questions that are addressed by this work are: Is the observed Higgs Boson the one predicted by the Standard Model? How does one explain the large disparity between the weak scale and the Planck scale? What are the dark matter and dark energy in the universe? Is there CP violation in the neutrino sector and is it the origin of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in the Universe? Why are neutrino masses so small? 

This project will look beyond the SM at the highest energies possible or through precision measurements. Supersymmetry (SUSY), if it exists, could yield candidates for dark matter. The mystery of dark energy may be related to the Higgs boson, which was discovered at the LHC. If extra spacetime dimensions exist, they may be accessible at the LHC. This Columbia research program will also tackle the question of the nature of fundamental particles, such as the Higgs boson (ATLAS) and neutrinos (MicroBooNE, SBN, DUNE, and CCM), and, through precision measurements, probe higher energy scales. MicroBooNE and the future long and short-baseline neutrino oscillation experiments will address unanswered questions related to the number of neutrino species and fundamental symmetries between neutrinos and antineutrinos. DUNE will furthermore probe for new physics which manifests itself through rare processes, such as proton decay.

The Columbia group will build on their existing education and outreach efforts, engaging the full spectrum from high school students, high school teachers, and undergraduates in understanding and doing high energy physics. The group will also invest in efforts to bring the excitement of the science to the general public through individual faculty outreach efforts (lectures, tours, etc.),  structured programs like Columbia’s Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site, and their Science-on-Hudson series of public lectures. A goal of the Columbia program is to engage under-represented groups to participate in these activities. 

The Columbia hardware development efforts provide postdocs, graduate students and undergraduate students with valuable skills and hands-on experience with state-of-the-art instrumentation, an increasingly rare opportunity. Furthermore, the group’s recent efforts in readout and trigger for DUNE have enabled new, cross-disciplinary collaboration between physics and computer science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Columbia program is deeply involved in research at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN in Geneva, Switzerland, where Columbia scientists collaborate on the ATLAS experiment. The LHC is the world’s most powerful particle accelerator, used to explore fundamental questions about the universe, including the origin of particle masses, the nature of Dark Matter, the matter-antimatter asymmetry, and the existence of new particles and forces. Following the discovery of the Higgs boson, which earned the 2013 Nobel Prize in Physics, the ATLAS collaboration focuses on studying the Higgs boson’s properties and searching for new particles and phenomena, areas of special interest for the Columbia group.

Although the current understanding of particle physics is viewed as incomplete, ongoing searches for new physics signatures offer a path toward deeper knowledge of the universe. So far, collider experiments, including those by the Columbia group, have only ruled out certain new physics possibilities. However, as the LHC upgrades to higher energies and intensities, its discovery potential grows. Part of Columbia’s contribution involves developing upgrades for the ATLAS detector electronics to handle these higher intensities. The first stage, with a critical electronic component developed by Columbia, is now operational, and preparations for a full electronics replacement are underway. The LHC continues to be an invaluable resource for advancing our understanding of the universe and will remain a cornerstone of scientific research for decades.

Another key component of the Columbia program is neutrino physics, specifically the study of neutrino oscillations. Neutrinos are elusive particles that interact weakly and are unique for having no strong or electric charge. There are three types of neutrinos, each associated with a corresponding charged lepton, including the electron. In the Standard Model, neutrinos were thought to be massless, but experiments over the past two decades have shown they have tiny masses, causing them to change types as they travel, a phenomenon known as neutrino oscillations. The discovery of neutrino oscillations, which won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physics for Takaaki Kajita and Arthur B. McDonald, has opened up new questions about neutrino properties and their role in the universe.

The Columbia group has been investigating several critical questions through their involvement in the MicroBooNE and SBN experiments at Fermilab. These experiments aim to search for evidence of a fourth type of "sterile" neutrino. The potential discovery of sterile neutrinos would be groundbreaking for particle physics and is a leading focus in the neutrino community. Columbia has played a prominent role in analyzing data from the MiniBooNE experiment, which showed significant anomalies that could suggest the existence of sterile neutrinos. In 2018, MiniBooNE reported new results that doubled its data and continued to show these anomalies.

Columbia’s work on the MicroBooNE experiment sought to resolve the MiniBooNE anomalies, specifically an excess of low-energy neutrino events. Using a 170-ton liquid argon detector, the Columbia group has made substantial contributions, including developing the detector readout and leading several physics analyses. One of the group's first analyses ruled out the hypothesis that the MiniBooNE excess was due to a mis-estimated photon background, and they continued to lead efforts to explore other beyond-Standard Model physics interpretations using MicroBooNE’s full data set.

For the SBN program, Columbia has built the readout system for the time projection chamber at the experiment’s near detector, which has been fully commissioned. The experiment is now preparing to begin beam operations, and Columbia is taking a leadership role in the first SBN search for light sterile neutrinos, an effort expected to provide definitive answers regarding their existence.

Education and outreach are central to Columbia’s program. The group engages in a range of activities, from individual faculty outreach efforts, such as lectures and tours, to more structured programs like the NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at Nevis. The group places a special emphasis on reaching underrepresented groups for the research program, and for over 14 years, more than half of the REU participants have been women, and nearly a third have been minorities.  One of the most notable outreach initiatives for the Columbia group is the monthly "Science-on-Hudson" public lecture series at Columbia’s Nevis Laboratory, which regularly attracts over 150 attendees and explains the physics research program to the general public.

In addition to its work in particle physics, Columbia's neutrino group is also collaborating with industry to develop new types of cyclotrons that could be used to enhance the production of medical isotopes, further extending the program’s impact beyond fundamental research.
